cluster_relations.rel_desc: Scientists studying black holes are the community engaged in the study of black holes.
The holographic principle is an important concept within theoretical physics.
The black hole information paradox is an important concept within theoretical physics.
General relativity is cited as an example of a gravitational theory tested using black holes.
cluster_relations.subject_class_label: Fundamental Physics Theories Tested with Black Holes

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: in contexts such as black hole tests
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ExampleRelation: general relativity is one such theory

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Quantum gravity is given as an example of the proposed new physics beyond general relativity.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a concept belongs to or is studied within a particular research field or discipline.
args.justification: Both relations describe specific theoretical concepts (holographic principle, black hole information paradox) as important concepts within the research field of theoretical physics; a unified predicate capturing concept–field membership is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a community or group of researchers is actively engaged in work within a particular research field.
args.justification: This relation links a scientific community (scientists studying black holes) to the field/activity they are engaged in (study of black holes), which is a participation relation rather than simple set membership.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a set, category, or collection includes a particular member or example.
args.justification: The subject is a plural category ('gravitational theories') and the object a specific theory ('general relativity'); the intended semantics is that general relativity is one member of the broader set.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is an illustrative instance or example of the broader category or idea given by the object.
args.justification: The text explicitly states that quantum gravity is given as an example of proposed new physics; the predicate 'is_example_of' directly captures this illustrative membership relation.
Both relations represent membership of theoretical concepts within a research domain (theoretical physics), forming a coherent class of concept–domain membership links.
This relation captures how a research community engages in a specific field of study, which is distinct from abstract concept membership and merits its own participation-focused class.

Both relations express that a specific entity (general relativity, quantum gravity) is a member or example of a broader set or category (gravitational theories, new physics); grouping them under a combined membership/example class is appropriate.
Concept–research-field links represent associative domain membership rather than strict identity or causality, fitting best under a broad ASSOCIATION group.
The relation describes an active role of agents (scientists) participating in a research activity/field, which aligns with an AGENCY-focused group.
Both relations describe membership or example-type associations between specific theories/frameworks and broader categories, which are associative rather than causal or temporal.
